episode.title: National Cable and Telecommunications Association v. Gulf Power Company

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: submitted We'll hear argument next in number oh oh eight thirty-two, National Cable and Telecommunications Association versus Gulf Power Company.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
Under the Pole Attachments Act, the FCC is required to regulate pole attachments to ensure the the rates, terms, and conditions for those attachments be just and reasonable.
The question presented in this case is whether two particular types of c- attachments are covered by the act.
The first is an attachment to provide cable television service and commingled Internet access.
That means that on, over that particular wire at the particular time is traveling both cable television service and Internet access at different frequencies.
The second type of attachment at issue is an attachment used to provide wireless telecommunications services.
The FCC determined that, and the most natural reading of the act requires that both types of attachments are covered.
The operative provision, the basic coverage provision, defines a pole attachment as any attachment by a cable television system or provider of telecommunications service.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Where do we find the text of the act?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: In the appendix to the, our petition for certiorari right at the end.
The language that I'm talking about now is on page two hundred and five A.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: it's, I'm sure it's in our brief also, but it's not in app- it's not separately set forth in an appendix there.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: But the, in , sect- the section I'm referring to now is section two twenty-four A four.

It says, the term pole attachment means, any attachment by a cable television system or provider of telecommunications service to a pole, duct, conduit, or right-of-way owned or controlled by a utility.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And don't you think it's implicit in that definition that it mean, in , not just an attachment by, but also an attachment for the purpose of the business of?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They couldn't put up a billboard, you know yo- you know, i-

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I think that the use of the term, in particular, cable television system, it has to be part of the cable television system, which could be reasonably construed to mean the the network of of of devices that are used to provide cable television system service to people.
I think that's correct, and I think probably the same thing is true with the...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: is Inter- Internet access part of a cable television system?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: The FCC hasn't reached a conclusion on that yet because what the FCC concluded, and I think what the la- most natural reading of the statute leads to the conclusion as well that if an attachment is an attachment that's used to provide cable television system service, the fact, or it's used by a cable television system, the fact that it's also used for something else doesn't exclude...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: If it still is well, it would still be.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: cover- covered under E, under under the telecommunications rate.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I I wouldn't quite say that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: it has purported to reserve that question, hasn't it?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I I wouldn't quite put it that way.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Where where do we find that?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: That is on page eighty, the best place to start with is eighty-seven A at paragraph thirty-three.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: you think that that issue is up in this case, then, whether...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: saying that the that the that the decision here rests upon that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: here is not whether the court of appeals was right, it's whether the commission was wrong.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: rate issue was the the the the court of appeals did not d- did not address, and I don't even think was presented to the court of appeals, what the proper rate is to apply.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, but theoretically it could be...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: as a result of that, we don't know? We cannot tell.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I I don't think that that's correct, what...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: for us to say to the agency, you've got to explain to us what you at least believe your jurisdictional basis is for this because, depending on whether your jurisdictional basis is the general provision or D or E may affect that that that may, the the result in in this case could be dependent on that.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I think the agency was very clear that it jurisdi-, its basis for jurisdiction is A four, which is the basic coverage provision of the act, it could, it, and it said...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: then that forces u-, in other words, you're saying the agency made it clear that it was neither D nor E.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right, and I agree. The it, You can infer, you're right. You can infer that...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: and they said it could be D because it c-, we're not, we don't have to decide whether it is a t- a-, whether the Internet access part of it is a a provision of, is a a cable service because if it's a cable service, it's covered under the terms of D.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay, but if i- if it's...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: if it's under D, we we review it strictly within D terms.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: then we've got to decide another issue.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: But I I think the agency was quite clear, and they pinned their...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: question of then whether it's D or not is, just has to do with the question of what the right rate is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Feldman, are you saying that it's an...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: academic question what the precise rate is when we're dealing with a court of appeals decision that says that's irrelevant because there is no authority at all...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: think th- that the point is that is not a a, even almost not a, probably not a possible reading of the statute, and certainly not the one that the FCC, once the FCC adopted a...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: you're asking us to say that F, the FCC does have authority.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: basic question is does it have any authority to come up with a just and reasonable rate at all.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And I I would I would a-

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: also the case that we are being forced to decide an issue which, if the agency were clear and came out and said it's D, we wouldn't have to decide.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I I don't think that that's right because whet- whether the agency says it's D or not, the fact is that A four covers this.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, yeah, but that's the, that's one of the...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: realize that, but that iss- that issue, it seems to me, is not a difficult one.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: doing that, which I can go into.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I can give you another another plausible explanation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: of why Congress put cable only in the later section and in the earlier section just talked about...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: anything else that cable does will be telecommunications.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Well, if Congress thought that again, the the result of of if that were true could be that the E rate might apply to this thing, but it would still be that the E rate applied.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But let's assume that FCC determines that this is not telecommunications.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And I think they have determined for the time being...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: and you have a a hybrid cable.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: If it turned out that this additional the addition of Internet access meant that it was neither cable nor telecommunications ser- service, that that that additional service was neither...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: neither of those, then the FCC would have to figure out what the just and reasonable rate would be for that.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: more for a hybrid than for a pure cable.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: possible the FCC could do that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: the FCC didn't and why the statute...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I'm wondering why that can be because it has no jurisdiction over pure Internet.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: but then I, but my question is why can it possibly charge more for the hybrid...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I don't want to justify that decision because what the FCC decided is that that wouldn't be what it would want to do, and it, if it it decided that if it's a hybrid like...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They're they're they're they're saying even though the section says you charge this rate when it's cable only, we're going to say you can charge this rate when it's cable plus Internet.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: Yes, yes because I think that what Congress wanted to specify when it said when it's cable only is it wanted to ensure that, and and this is actually fairly clear, is when the cable companies went into the into the business of providing telephone service to people, that they would ha- be charged the same rate as the telecommunications providers who were newly added to the act.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: If you ignore the the doctrine inclusio unius, exclusio alterius, and you say these are the rates when it's cable...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And the FCC has come and said, these are also the rates when it's cable...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: If that were true, that could lead to the conclusion that the FCC's choice of rate here was wrong and maybe it should have chosen the E rate or some other rate.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Feldman, do I understand your argument that if we should reverse the Eleventh Circuit and say there is FCC jurisdiction, then it would go then it would have to await your ongoing rulemaking to determine which category this is, or would there be something for the Eleventh Amendment to do on remand once we say you have jurisdiction to do something?

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I think that that if the issue was preserved before the Eleventh Circuit, they would have jurisdiction to determine what the right rate is, and they d-, look at what what the FCC's reasoning was and whether, you know, the the various conclusions the FCC reached in coming to the D rate.

turn.speaker: peter_d_keisler
turn.label: Mr. Peter D. Keisler
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: the attachment of a cable system.

turn.speaker: peter_d_keisler
turn.label: Mr. Peter D. Keisler
turn.text: Well, it's an attachment by a cable television system to the pole, and the system itself is defined as a set of closed transmission paths and associated signal and generation reception control equipment that is designed to provide cable services which include video programming.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But but but but but but that means that they can get away with it only if they are correct that in in choosing to apply the D rate.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: selection of the D rate is wrong, then their assumption that they don't have to get into that question is also wrong.

turn.speaker: peter_d_keisler
turn.label: Mr. Peter D. Keisler
turn.text: It could only be wrong in two circumstances.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You you say they haven't sought cert on it, but but they're they're the respondents here.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, but it seems to me they're they're entitled to defend the the the outcome below on any reaso- on any ground.

turn.speaker: peter_d_keisler
turn.label: Mr. Peter D. Keisler
turn.text: But they haven't defended on that ground, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: talk for a minute about the attachment of wireless...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Telecommunications, we we don't have a position.

turn.speaker: peter_d_keisler
turn.label: Mr. Peter D. Keisler
turn.text: But but the packing of multiple services into this wire, that was considered a good thing.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Internet is concerned, you wouldn't be kicked off.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What is this conductory citation here?

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: It's fourty-seven USC, section two two four B one.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And the page reference again? Excuse me.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: It's two oh six A of the appendix to the petition.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: B one says, in pertinent part, that the commission shall regulate the rates, terms, and conditions for pole attachments.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, i- it's it's even funnier than that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But it includes nailing up a wireless thing.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Well, the government's, on this issue and also on the inter issue, Internet issue, they've they've ignored some of the basic rules of reading a statute, and what they've ignored here is the basic rule that you have to read the whole statute and the meaning that any of the phrases, like any attachment here, is informed by context.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But before you turn to the next section, staying with A four for a minute...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: any attachment to a pole, duct, conduit, or right-of-way owned or controlled by a utility.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Does that language apply to what we're talking about?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: literally the definition does apply regardless of the purpose of the attachment.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: If that's if you stop reading if you stop reading the statute there, you could come to that conclusion, but you need to read the whole statute, and if you do, sir, with respect, in D and E there are the two rate formulas.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: may I just cut you short because I want to get m- th- one thought out of my mind.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you r- read it as saying provided that the attachment is used either for a D or an E purpose?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's So, those are exclusive uses.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: under the explu-, w- we'll get to there in a second, but there, it's under the...

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Under the exclusio unius principle, D and E are the only purposes that are authorized here, and others are intended to be excluded.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I mean, as far as I read D and E, they address a a typical, but not most important, regulatory problem.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: I think there's several answers to that question.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: We're We're off on the on the other...

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: to the other issue, but let me just answer the question quickly, if I could.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: you don't if if if you characterize B the right way.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: You'd have to, in order to come to that reading, you'd have to separate this this very detailed set of rate formulas from their general jurisdiction to regulate.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: for anything other than cable and wire service.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: whereas for those areas that are within its special expertise, cable and...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I'm glad you agree with that. I just wonder what's...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: so odd about Congress giving regulatory authority...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: regulatory agency and then taking out two areas, that it happens to be, that the industry is particularly interested in and negotiating a specific formula, while leaving others, times I've seen it a thousand times in regulatory statutes, leaving others for the agency to proceed under normal, ordinary, just, and reasonable rate setting authority.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: I I think another answer, and again, I do want to return to the wireless issue because it does tend to get lost in the shuffle here.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: The Off- White House's Office of Telecommunications Policy wrote two letters to Congress expressing that concern when the act was con- being considered, and Congress said, in the legislative history, quite clearly, we're giving the FCC a very narrow grant of jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: very narrow because they're only talking about attachments to utility poles.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It's a very narrow aspect of the utilities' overall operations.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Not only are they talking about attachments to utility poles, but they're only talking about attachments to utility poles for two kinds of services.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: two kinds of rates, these are the formulas for those two.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: If you, well, certainly if you read this canon, if you read the statute with the canon of exp- of expressio unius, you there needs to...

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Well, a- again, i- th- you would...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: not only fixes rates, it requires access.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: w- what you mean by associated equipment, I suppose, is I don't know, joint boxes, lightening arresters, things of that sort.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Associated equipment is equipment that is used to make the wires and the cables work.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why couldn't associated equipment mean for the for a wireless company, I guess very few of these wireless companies are entirely wireless.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So, why couldn't the wireless boxes that they nail on these on these poles as pole attachment be deemed associated equipment of these wires that they use elsewhere?

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Well, again, it's wires, cables, and associated equipment, and not...

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: and asso- and associated wires and cables.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: to be associated with the very wires and cables that...

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: ejusdem generis principles, in that phrase, wires, cables, and associated equipment, the associated equipment is subordinate to the words that precede it and is delimited by those two words.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Can you just tell me, where does the term, associated equipment, what section was that in?

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: It's in section two two four D two on page two oh eight A of the...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: when given given the fact, that as somebody pointed out, I guess Justice Scalia pointed out earlier, the wireless companies always have some wires.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right. It's got to be a...

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: I I And I think also one last quick point on on wireless.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: sites that are used by a utility.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: sites that are owned by utility companies.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: to mandatory carriage of wire- of of of of wireless?

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: the ar- that's the government's argument.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: This, under this FCC's und- under the FCC's reading of this statute, which is i- impermissible u- if you read the whole statute, they have they have decided to take this revolutionary expansion of their jurisdiction to regulate this tiny piece of the wireless siting market.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: could I ask you a question that gets you back to the other, to the other issue? I- Is it i- is the government correct that you lose if the, if even if the rate applied by the FCC is wrong, that the only thing you're asking us is to say that the FCC has no jurisdiction? It wouldn't even matter if the FCC should have been treating this under E as telecommunications.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: they didn't say it would be treated under D.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: we're going to use the same rate that Congress specifies in in D.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: But but that's indeed what they wh- what they've done.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: phone company is exempted from the statute.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is is that because they have their own poles?

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: They have very few of their own poles.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well I thought the purpose of this and I'm really asking this question because I want to hear what your argument is on the main point in this case, if it's different from what you've already said.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Right, and I I you know understand that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, let's talk about the jurisdictional language...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: narrowing is language that picks out two categories of rate setting.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: The jurisdictional language is not the as broad as it may appear to be.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: toasters and it doesn't include billboards, I agree.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Yes, but it also doesn't include comingled cable and Internet service.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Well, there's an awkwardness that I don't understand.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Well, Congress has talked sort of out of both sides of its u- mouth about the Internet.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: In the in that That's how you read...

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: But these cable companies are are not mom and pop shops anymore.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: biggest companies in the United States.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: in the legislative history, anything that indicates that Congress wanted to take this benefit away from the cable systems if they were also offering Internet access?

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: L- l- let me i- the answer is yes, and it comes in the definition of a cable system.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Well, I'm, what I'm arguing here...

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: if the if it gets into the Internet business, it gets put on the same footing as if you're a local phone company...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Whatever whatever the, utility wants to charge. Right.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And that's the price of getting into the Internet for a cable system.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It gives up it gives up rate...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is its main competitor the local phone...

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: there are two big competitors in this business, the local phone company which is unregulated, and the cable company which is seeking this...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: how many poles do the local phone companies own own in relation to the the utilities that you're representing?

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: About eighty or eighty-five percent of poles are owned by the utility companies, fifteen, twenty percent are owned...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: effect of what Justice Ginsburg is talking about is going to be significantly different in relation to the utilities from what it is in relation to local phone companies.

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: Indeed, but the the re- I think the relevant comparison of that would be how many the phone company, i- it's putting it's putting the...

turn.speaker: thomas_p_steindler
turn.label: Mr. Thomas P. Steindler
turn.text: phone company on, more or less, the same...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: you're you're you're the ones holding holding the market position.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: the the the the phone companies whatever you want for their use of your...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Steindler, is am I wrong in thinking May I just ask one question? Am I wrong in thinking that a local phone company can be a utility within the meaning of the statute?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Indeed, that I'm wrong, or indeed, it is?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Feldman, you have two minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I think it might be worthwhile to point out that the F the FCC's construction of the act is entitled to deference and is at least a reasonable construction of the act.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: quite, I mean, in fairness to what th- h- he was arguing, I mean, a person, were this statute not to apply, could still go either to the local telephone company regulators, which I imagine they would do in the case of the local phone company, could go to the local public utilities commission, or could go to the Federal Power Commission and ask them for the same kind of protection that the FCC might give them if this act does apply.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I'm I guess, I'm not awa-

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: I'm not aware of what the basis of the Federal Power Commission's...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right, but what Cong- what what Congress...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I suggest, that I just, I'm not tot- -- I'm not...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: sure about what the l- what the authority of local utility...

turn.speaker: james_a_feldman
turn.label: Mr. James A. Feldman
turn.text: is over the poles as opposed to the rates...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Could they not I I'm imagining I just heard about...

turn.speaker: the_marshal
turn.label: Mr. The Marshal
turn.text: The honorable court is now adjourned until tomorrow at ten o'clock.
